 Richard Dawkins posited his theory of memes suggesting that cultural information is passed from one mind to another via a replicator. Using the biological metaphor of genes, Dawkins says that memes (beliefs, practices, morals, tastes, etc) propigate in society like genes. They are often bundled into packages with other ideas (memeplexes) and passed on through language and demonstration.
 
 The theory is attractive because of its creative speculation and because Dawkins offers his own meme in a way that is accessible to the general populace. Dawkins idea is epistemically encompassing. Memes include all information used to form philosophical ideas (like metaphysics, epistemology, empericism, ethics, etc.) as well as cultural ideas (esthetics, language, sociology, etc.) as well as any other idea that the mind can generate.
 
 To read the title of this strand ("Religion is a product of evolution") through Dawkins' spectacles one would acknowledge that the title represents a meme which resides in a memeplex of associated information. We could call the title ("Religion is a product of evolution") a memeplex, but for simplicities sake I will refer to it here as a meme. For each person the memeplex within which this meme is located will be unique. However, we might postulate that other people identifying with this meme may have certain general similarities between memeplexes (ie: nature is fascinating, faith is subjective, the world is accessible through reason and perception, etc.). 
 
 What is genuinely curious is that people who share this same meme ("Religion is a product of evolution") might also have opposing memes within their memeplex. For example, the woman who thinks, "Religion is a product of evolution" might also possess the meme, "The natural world that we percieve is the sum and substance of reality." While another woman who thinks "Religion is a product of evolution" might also possess the meme, "The natural world that we percieve is only a part of reality." One memeplex would deny religious revelation and the other would be open to religious revelation. Both contain the meme "Religion is a product of evolution," and might therefore identify themselves with the basics of Dawkins meme theory. I might add that the later woman would identify with Dawkins without disassociating herself from the plausibility of religious revelation.
 
 Maybe Dawkins thesis has less potential to destroy religion memes than your statement suggests.
